citation.article-title: Lactobacillus koreensis sp. nov., isolated from the traditional Korean food kimchi
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Lactobacillus koreensis sp. nov.
Lactobacillus koreensis (ko.re.en′sis. N.L. masc. adj. koreensis of Korea, referring to the isolation of the type strain from a traditional Korean food).
Cells are Gram-stain-positive, motile, catalase-negative, facultatively anaerobic, non-spore-forming, curved rods (1.4–2.0×3.0–5.0 µm).
Colonies grown on MRS agar for 1 day are beige, circular and convex with smooth surfaces, <1 mm in diameter.
Grows in 7 % NaCl and at 15 °C but not at 42 °C.

Acid is produced from d-xylose, d-galactose, melibiose, d-arabitol and aesculin but not from d-arabinose, l-xylose, d-adonitol, methyl β-d-xylopyranoside, d-mannitol, methyl α-d-glucopyranoside, N-acetylglucosamine, maltose, lactose or l-arabitol.
Weakly positive responses are found with l-arabinose, d-ribose and d-fructose.
Ammonia is not produced from arginine hydrolysis.
Lactic acid and acetic acid but not ethanol are detected as metabolic end products from glucose.
Gas is produced from glucose and gluconate.
Produces d- and l-lactic acids at a ratio of 30 : 70 (v/v).
The peptidoglycan type is A4α l-Lys–d-Asp.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 49 mol%, as determined by HPLC.
The type strain, DCY50T ( = KCTC 13530T = JCM 16448T), was isolated from the traditional Korean fermented food kimchi.
